questions.question: The rate of heat transfer from a fin is directly proportional to:

A long fin is made of copper with a thermal conductivity of 400 W/mK. The fin is 10 cm long and has a cross-sectional area of 1 cm2. The heat transfer coefficient on the fin surface is 20 W/m2K. If the base temperature of the fin is 100°C, what is the heat transfer rate through the fin?
How does the thermal conductivity of liquids compare to that of solids?

The heat transfer rate through a long fin is 100 W. The thermal conductivity of the fin material is 200 W/mK. The heat transfer coefficient on the fin surface is 20 W/m2K. If the base temperature of the fin is 100°C, what is the temperature at the tip of the fin?
What is one of the assumptions made in the analysis of fins?

answers.a: Constant thermal conductivity of the material
answers.b: Constant and uniform convection heat transfer coefficient over the entire surface of the fin
answers.c: Steady operation with no heat generation in the fin
